security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill. No executable code, no network access, no file system access beyond standard AI tool permissions, no environment variable access. Provides templates and guidance for SRS documentation.

content.user_title: Create formal SRS documents with IEEE 830 templates
content.value_statement: Writing formal Software Requirements Specifications can be time consuming and error prone. This skill provides IEEE 830 compliant templates and checklists to help generate structured, professional SRS documents quickly and consistently.
actual_capabilities: Generate complete SRS documents using IEEE 830 standard structure
Apply validation checklists to verify requirement quality
Create functional and non-functional requirement specifications
Use MoSCoW prioritization for requirement classification
Follow consistent ID conventions for requirements tracking
limitations: Does not execute code or access external systems
Does not validate requirements against existing codebase
Does not generate test cases or implementation code
Does not integrate with project management tools

use_cases.title: Professional SRS documentation
use_cases.description: Create formal, standardized Software Requirements Specifications for stakeholder review and development teams.

use_cases.title: Requirements quality assurance
use_cases.description: Validate gathered requirements against IEEE 830 checklists to ensure completeness and traceability.

use_cases.title: Clear requirement specifications
use_cases.description: Receive well-structured requirements with proper ID conventions, priority levels, and acceptance criteria.

prompt_templates.title: Basic SRS creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a complete Software Requirements Specification document using the IEEE 830 standard. Include: 1. Introduction with purpose, scope, definitions, and references. 2. Overall description with product perspective, functions, user characteristics, constraints, and dependencies. 3. Specific requirements with external interfaces, functional requirements, performance requirements, and design constraints. Use {PROJECT_NAME} as the example project.

prompt_templates.title: Functional requirements
prompt_templates.scenario: Add functional requirements to existing SRS
prompt_templates.prompt: Add functional requirements section to my SRS document. For each requirement include: unique ID using FR-XXX format, description using 'shall' for mandatory requirements, priority using MoSCoW method, inputs, processing steps, outputs, error handling, and acceptance criteria. Focus on {FEATURE_AREA} functionality.

prompt_templates.title: NFR specification
prompt_templates.prompt: Create non-functional requirements section for my SRS. Include performance, security, reliability, usability, and maintainability requirements. Each NFR should have measurable criteria with specific targets, priority level, and verification method. Use NFR-XXX-ID format.

prompt_templates.title: Requirements prioritization
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the following requirements and apply MoSCoW prioritization. For each item, assign Must Have, Should Have, Could Have, or Won't Have status. Provide rationale for each prioritization decision. Identify any potential conflicts between requirements and suggest resolutions.

output_examples.input: Create an SRS document for a project management application
output: 1.1 Purpose: This SRS defines requirements for TaskMaster, a web-based project management application
1.2 Scope: User management, task tracking, team collaboration, and reporting features
2.1 Product Perspective: Standalone web app integrating with existing SSO providers
FR-001: System shall allow users to create, edit, and delete projects - Priority: Must Have
FR-002: System shall generate weekly progress reports - Priority: Should Have
NFR-PERF-001: System shall display dashboard within 2 seconds of login - Priority: Must Have

best_practices: Use 'shall' for mandatory requirements, 'should' for desirable, 'may' for optional
Write requirements that are unambiguous, complete, and verifiable with measurable criteria
Assign unique identifiers to each requirement for traceability throughout the project lifecycle
anti_patterns: Avoid vague terms like 'fast', 'user-friendly', or 'flexible' without specific metrics
Do not combine multiple requirements into single statements
Avoid adding implementation details or design constraints in requirements specifications

faq.question: Which AI platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, OpenAI Codex, and Claude Code. Each platform provides Read and Write tools for document creation.

faq.question: What is the maximum size for SRS documents?
faq.answer: There is no fixed limit. The template supports projects of any size by adding additional sections as needed.

faq.question: Can I customize the template for my organization?
faq.answer: Yes. Modify the template sections, ID conventions, or priority systems to match your organization's standards.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill runs entirely within your AI session. No data is sent to external servers beyond your AI provider.

faq.question: Why are my requirements marked as incomplete?
faq.answer: Check that each requirement has: unique ID, description with 'shall', priority, inputs, outputs, and acceptance criteria.

faq.question: How does this compare to other documentation skills?
faq.answer: This skill focuses specifically on IEEE 830 SRS standard with built-in validation. It provides more structured guidance than generic documentation templates.
